Name: Stahl und Eisen
Description:
This game's box cover and spectacularly illustrated board provide a thorough tour of WWI Germany's military-industrial complex, from a coal mine and iron and steel making through the production of massive artillery pieces and warships.

In play, it is a basic spin-and-move game, but the artwork by Johann B. Maier made for effective wartime propaganda at the time and remains today a vivid historical picture of the role of heavy industry during the Great War.

Name: The Game of Paul Pry
Description:
This is a mid-19th century party game subtitled I Hope I Don't Intrude, and takes its name from the popular comedy play Paul Pry, which premiered in 1825.

The game consists of a deck of 13 cards. Once card has the instructions, and list of 12 questions labelled A through L. Each letter corresponds to an answer card with possible responses numbered from 1 through 15.

One player has custody of the cards, and reads a question. The remaining players in turn pick a number from 1 to 15, and the player with the cards then reads off the corresponding answer.

For instance, to question L ("What most occupies your thoughts?"), potential answers range from "The fashions" and "My dinner" to "My own virtues" and "In building air castles". Presumably the answer generating the most laughs wins.

Name: Snitch
Description:
Snitch is a fast-paced game with social deduction and semi co-operative mechanics where players try to win the most money.

Each round one player selects the number of cards (characters) that must then be matched from the groups' cards (characters)- these are drawn from the deck and the players negotiate which cards (characters) they will contribute.

Each player contributes one card towards the pattern. If the players collectively complete the required pattern, everyone wins - if not, the group loses. Winners gain loot, the losers gain nothing - with the amount of loot determined by the number of cards matched. After 8 rounds, the winner is the player with the most loot.

There's always a chance though that one player was the Snitch - trying to make the group fail in order to win by themselves! The Snitch causes others to miss out on the loot, and steals some of their existing loot. Being the snitch at the right time is key to winning the game!

Players have a limited number of Snitch cards - when will you Snitch on your friends? When will they Snitch on you?! Everyone has to Snitch at some point...

Name: Card Goblins: Expansão Piratas
Description:
Pirate-themed expansion for Card Goblins, containing 15 cards. This expansion was released with the game during its crowdfunding campaign.

Shuffle these cards into the main deck and proceed as normal.

Name: Tiberius Who?
Description:
Tiberius Claudius Nero's father was lucky to escape execution by Octavian Caesar after the siege of Perusia in 40 BC. His parents took the infant Tiberius and fled from the blood-chilling vengeance of the future Emperor Augustus. As they made their perilous escape from Italy nobody gave a dried fig for the boy's prospects. So how could he possibly have become Augustus' heir and successor?

It is 11BC and the succession plans of Roman Emperor Caesar Augustus have suffered a calamity: his trusted friend, son-in-law and Heir-apparent, Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa, has died suddenly. There is a vacuum into which several talented men wish to step. Although they don’t yet know it, all of Augustus’s male heirs are also destined to die before him, and the man who succeeds in replacing Agrippa at Augustus’s right hand will ultimately become the Emperor of Rome, the most powerful man in the World.

The players take the roles of real Roman Noblemen, each having recently finished a term as Consul of Rome. This, plus ambition, qualifies them for the most prestigious jobs in the service of Augustus and the Empire.

Each of the 8 turns represents 3 years. In each turn Augustus asks the Nobles to do 6 jobs. The 6 jobs are depicted by Career Cards. The Nobles will use their influence with Augustus to get the first choice of the jobs. The jobs will help the Nobles in several areas that any Roman Noble must be seen to excel at, in order to rise above their fellows. They do this by placing cubes into the boxes of the main board as prescribed by the Career Cards. Those boxes include commanding Rome's Legions, Conquering new provinces, Governing the existing one, serving the gods of the State religion, helping Augustus in Rome, and hopefully being permitted to ride at Augustus' side through the Forum in a Triumph. Each Noble will try to marry into Augustus's family. And with the right collection of cubes a Noble can also be adopted as Augustus's Son.

—description from the publisher

Name: Wings of War: World War 2 – Dewoitine D520
Description:
Take your Wings of War game into the third dimension! Each historically-accurate, fully-painted miniature represents an aircraft from Wings of War: The Dawn of World War II. All miniatures come complete with maneuver deck and variable-altitude stand.

This French fighter aircraft, used largely for training purposes, saw limited combat.

—description from the publisher

Name: Age of Empires: Expandable Card Game – Nautical Expansion
Description: Age of Empires: Nautical is the only published expansion for the Age of Empires II ECG. Journeyman Press printed the expansion on April the 16th in 2001. The expansion comes with 160 cards and introduces the four (4) new civilizations - Franks, Japanese, Saracens, and Vikings; additionally, included are "Water Rules" and new scenarios.

Name: GearGrid
Description:
You blatantly lied on your CV and got hired by the world's best Gear Moving Factory. It is your first day at the job and the boss is smelling something fishy about the new recruits. He places you in the Ultra Modern Testing Grounds to test your skills. The one who ends up the best will start working... for others, tough luck.

Pick up gear tiles as quickly as possible and try to make right connections and fill up the board... 1-4 players, virtually no setup time and 1-3 minutes per round.

During a game, each player picks up gear tiles from the common pool and adds them to their own board. Each tile must be connected (diagonally or orthogonally) to the engine tile via coloured squares. If a player successfully connects 3 goal tiles with the engine tile so that goal tiles turn in the right direction, he scores 3 points for each. Each empty space on the board is worth -1 point at the end of the game.

Players must be careful, invalid connections might make whole sections of the board invalid and empty before the scoring. No two tiles may be connected via different colours, and a tile connected with two tiles that turn in two different directions is also invalid.

A round lasts between 1 and 3 minutes (players choice, depends on skill). The player with the best score is the winner.

Players may also choose to use or not use both sides of the gear tiles that easily show which gear turns in which direction. Using both sides makes the game much easier and it is recommended for the first games.

Name: Metro City Meltdown
Description:
Metro City Meltdown is a co-operative disaster management game for 1-4 players, which takes around 1 hour to play.
Taking place over 8 days, can you and your team protect and serve a city gone crazy and leave it whole at the end of your term? Sounds easy? Budget restraints, wild weather  and angry citizens all contribute to the city’s decline. 
Oh and don't get me started on the 100 foot tall dinosaurs or flying saucers...

The game takes place over 8 game days and players take the roles of city officials trying to protect the city from damage, rioting and disease.

Players use their city budgets to put crews into the city blocks to counter the news events that bring further disaster and ruin to the streets.

If you can survive to the end of your watch and have most of the city still up and running you win as a team. But lose too many city blocks or too many citizens to disease rioting or other dangers and you are fired and removed from office.

Each Player has a set of budget dice and there are federal budget dice which are divided among players according to the needs of the city.

Your budget can be assigned to actions to counter damage that takes place during the game. (Each round event cards dictate the headlines for that round and the damage that is caused). 
These actions could be to put out fires, heal the diseased, control unruly citizens repair infrastructure and reconnecting utilities. Be careful though you also need budget to move your work crews around the city.

If any of these issues get out of control they can spread very quickly. Losing 3 city blocks or all of the damage counters of any type results in instant dismissal from the City Disaster council and disgrace for your team.

Watch your HQ as well if that burns down or is damaged beyond repair the same result can take place.

With 4 difficulty levels this game can be a light entertaining game right through to nearly impossible odds. This might seem repressive but beating the game on Expert level is a great boost.
 Solo play can be played in the normal way but the Solo story mode involves scenarios that build upon each other.

Name: Star Wars: Angriff auf den Todesstern
Description:
The rebels are planning an attack on the Death Star, the
ultimate weapon of the Empire. Of course, a fleet of enemy spaceships immediately appears to the rebels way. Help the rebels to defeat these spaceships to end up to finally reach the Death Star.

Galactically cool dice game in which the STAR WARS fans help the rebels to their "Death Star Attack".

—description from the publisher (translated)

Die Rebellen planen einen Angriff auf den Todesstern, die ultimative Waffe des Imperiums. Natürlich stellt sich den Rebellen sofort eine Flotte von gegnerischen Raumschiffen in den Weg.
Helft den Rebellen diese Raumschiffe zu besiegen, um am Ende bis zum Todesstern vorzudringen.

Galaktisch cooles Würfelspiel, bei dem die STAR WARS Fans den Rebellen bei ihrem "Angriff auf den Todesstern" helfen.

—description from the publisher (German)

Name: Million Dollars But... The Game: Community Pack
Description:
Million Dollars, But... The Game Community Expansion Pack #1 comes with 100 new cards to either play standalone or combine with your core game to expand the fun.

75 new gold rule cards, 25 new black trigger cards, and one game rules card for standalone play. Each card is labeled with the community symbol for easy sorting.

The community cards feature the contributing community member's username, city, state, and country.

Name: PAM a game for children
Description:
PAM is an educational game for younger children. A set of 12 unique illustrated 3x3 grids features images of things that are Plants (P) or Animals (A) or Minerals (M) and the players must match the images on the grid with a similar image on a randomly drawn card. The first child to match three images in a row on his or her 3x3 grid is declared the winner. The cards include an illustration plus a written description to enhance reading skills.

Includes grids, cards, score chips, and instruction sheet. Can be played solitaire. Adult supervision is not required for older children.

Name: Ski the Mountain Card Game
Description:
Ski the Mountain is simple to learn, fun to play and can be enjoyed by families and experienced gamers alike.  An exciting game that will give you a ski fix without leaving your sofa.

Ski the Mountain is a highly competitive card game for up to 4 players, perfect for après ski. Players collect runs attempting to be the first to ski various combinations  or visit mountain restaurants. Watch out though there are lots of obstacles and distractions that can heed or hinder your progress.

Game contains over 100 cards of 7 different type, with photographic illustrations of skiing and mountains.

The aim of the game is to maximize the points scored by collecting ski runs.  Each turn players can take a piste cards.   These represent blue, red or black ski runs and in combination or alone allow players to take a run card. Using these cards players collect ski runs that are shown on the piste map.  Collecting the right combination of ski runs maximizes the points players score.

Points are scored by:
1. Using piste cards, players take a run card, each run has a varying score.
2. Across the piste map there are targets to reach, these are illustrated cards of mountain restaurants or skiing features.  By collecting the right run card these targets can be completed to add to players point totals.
3. Each player has a Grand Tour card that accumulate points as specific runs are collected.
4. There are also combined special runs on the piste map, that players race to complete.  The add varying amounts to players point totals
5. Finally there are the highly prized Bonus cards that add points for being the first to collect 3 or 4 blue, red or black runs or visit mountain restaurants.

During the game players will also be given Event cards.  These cards depict skiing related events that give player advantages or can stop your opponent.  Either way they add lots of fun to the game.

The game is fast and highly competitive with lots of laughter as players block or hinder each other, as they race to Ski the Mountain.

Name: Heroes of Normandie: South Lancashire Regiment
Description:
A fan-made 'Print & Play' punchboard that expands the Commonwealth Army of Heroes of Normandie. Made by Devil Pig's Games French forum moderator, GDuprez. Approved by Devil Pig Games' Yann and Clem as an 'official product'.


     one regular recruitment tile of the South Lancashire Regiment (3rd Infantry Division, 8th Infantry Brigade, 1st Battalion) with its recruitment options (Vickers Platoon, Fire Platoon, Bren Platoon).
     one High Command Recruitment Tile with Lt.Col. Gordon Duffin and his 'Artillery Spotter' ability.
     a few common Commonwealth units: a Daimler Armoured Car, a 6 Pounder AT Gun and a Sergeant NCO.
     a few other options 


______________________________

Quoting GDuprez, January 2018:
"As you know, during the past months the Pigs have been extremely busy (that’s putting it mildly): finalization of the card game KS as well as that of Age of Towers, add to that of course, the creation of Black Reach.

Meanwhile, since HoN and SoN were lying somewhat dormant, I tried to create units, tiles, markers and other options. Thanks to Clem and Yann who generously gave precious advice and granted access to the rich graphic library of Devil Pig, I have been equipped with both intel and means to embark on this adventure which is in all quite new to me."

Name: Węgrów 1863
Description:
Game covers battle of WÄ™grów, one of the most important skirmishes of January Uprising in the Russian Partition of Poland. It uses "Napoleon" system.

Battle took place February 3, 1863 near WÄ™grów in east Masovia. On January 22, Polish partisans, under the command of the WÅ‚adysÅ‚aw JabÅ‚onowski and Jan MatliÅ„ski liberated a town from Russian forces. Here Poles established a military base, in a few days gathering almost 3,500 soldiers, mostly poorly armed, with about 500 scythe armed volunters, known as "Kosynierzy" (Scythemen).

Russians decided to recapture WÄ™grów with quick attack of the combined force forces of a 1,000-strong infantry unit with artillery, led by colonel Georgi Papaafanasopulo. Poles, threatened by encirclement, decided to retreat from the town. About 500 scythemen were ordered cover the Polish retreat. Scythemen attacked the Russian left flank and routed Russian cavalry squadron and cannons. Thanks to their action, biggest part of the Polish forces managed to left the town, but almost all attacking scythemen were killed by Russian infantry fire.

Game covers whole battle in three scenarios.

Name: British vs Pirates: Volume 2 – South Sea Alliance
Description:
Full faction add-on introducing the South Sea Alliance faction to expand British Vs Pirates: Volume II with in addition to the French Navy and Buccaneers factions.

This add-on features two new ship classes to the game such as the Junk and the Turtle Ship.

This add-on features:


     20  D6 dice (purple)


Ship miniatures (purple):


     2  Sloop
     3  Junk
     4  Turtle


Additional miniatures (purple):


     1  Fort


Cards:


     1  Fort Card
     27 Skill Cards
     9  Ship Cards
     6  Captain Cards


Tokens:


     6  Crew Tokens

Name: Monopoly: Howden Editiion
Description:
Monopoly is a roll-and-move game where players move around the game board buying or trading properties, developing their properties with houses and hotels. When opponents land on players owned property, the owning player collects rent from the landing player. Owning sets of properties increases the rent paid to the player who owns them, by the player who lands on the square. The ultimate goal is to have the most money and drive opponents into bankruptcy.

From the rear of the box:

Howden, originally Heaffudene, grew at a crossing point (Bridgewater) along the Old Derwent (Hailgate) after Lake Humber had started to silt up.

The town has a history that starts before the Domesday Book and has several royal connections, King Edgar gave his first wife Howden Manor, William the Conqueror gave the church (later developed into the Minster) to the Bishop of Durham and King John gave Howden the right to hold an annual horse fair.

Howden was a coaching town and although it does not have a railway, it is the M62 that brings people here today.  AVisitor can enjoy the Georgian architecture around the Minster, shops and cafes around the Market Place, a community venue in the Shire Hall, a walk around the nature reserve of Howden Marsh or recreational time in The Ashes.

Local firms have helped to bring Howden MONOPOLY to fruition to celebrate The Ashes 90th anniversary.  This edition is about the comunity, by the communityand for the community.  Enjoy.

PROPERTIES
BROWN
The Bowman's / Wellington Hotel
LIGHT BLUE
Howden Station / Sacred Heart R. C. Church / Howden Methodist Church
PINK
War Memorial / Market Cross / Briggs Fountain
ORANGE
Parsons Lane / Treeton Road / Hailgate
RED
Howden CofE Infant School / Howden Junior School / Howden School
YELLOW
Vicar Lane / Market Place / Bridgegate
GREEN
Wren / E-Buyer / Press Association
DARK BLUE
Ashes Playing Field / Howden Minster
STATIONS
Howdens Manufacturing & Distribution / Howdens Worthwhile For All Concerned / Howdens Serving The Small Builder / Howdens Kitchens & Joinery
UTILITIES
Howden Marsh / Howden Show
TAXES
Ashes Playing Fields Trust / Shire Hall Restoration

Name: Star Trek: Attack Wing – 4th Wing Patrol Ship Card Pack
Description:
The 4th Wing Patrol Ship is a Jem'Hadar Attack Ship class ship. As a card pack, it comes with all the cards and tokens required for play.

It is a part of card pack wave 3.

Name: National Razor
Description:
In the early morning’s mist, the clatter of the tumbril’s wheels on the cobblestone echo through the streets of Paris. It brings a gruesome feast -consumed in rhythmic chopping- the National Razor is the gluttonous ouroboros of the revolution. Over the paranoid whisperings in the breadlines, and plastered rumors on the broadsheets, you sense that the revolution hangs by a thread. Will you be able to draw it back from the abyss, or will the final thump on the scaffold see your head in a basket?

Giving careful homage to the themes of the period, play one of six factions vying for dominance of revolutionary France. Each faction has eight historical leaders to choose from and five unique asymmetrical agendas to push though in an attempt to gain control of the revolution.

The game includes mechanics to coerce obedience, punish betrayal, or cooperatively reach mutual goals- allowing players to pick a path forward that best suits them. Each agenda proposed comes with a pool of 'largess' for players to distribute to win support for their machinations. Conversely, successfully sending an opposing faction's leader 'to the Chop' gains them, in addition the points scored, the trophy of a head on a pike.

National Razor is played in five rounds. Each round begins with players simultaneously selecting a leader for their faction and secretly choosing what their faction will focus on that round. All players then reveal their leaders, and the leader with the best rank becomes the First Citizen to begin the game play.

On a player's turn they can play any number of follower cards, buy improvements and titles, but they must play one of their five Agenda cards.  Agendas come with a pool of Largess -follower cards- that the active player proposes to give to players if her Agenda passes. Players then simultaneously vote on the fate of the Agenda using  Yes and No cards and may add modifiers if they feel particularly strongly about the outcome.

Player decisions also advance a token along the Terror Track. When a Terror hits, the game state changes in unforeseen ways that encourage and reward aggressive behavior. The most aggressive behavior being attempting to send an opposing faction leader 'to the Chop.' This is done by proving that your incriminating evidence is legit by naming what the faction's chosen focus for the round is (thereby showing you have successfully infiltrated their faction). If the opposing faction is able to show the named focus from their unselected pile, the Chop attempt fails. If the named focus is correct however, the opposing faction leader is removed from the game, the accuser gets the bounty listed on the deceased character's card, and gains a  trophy card showing a head on a pike to demonstrate how brutal their faction is.

After all factions have taken a turn, the round is over. All players with leaders still alive reveal their chosen focus, gaining the special benefits they provide. If its the 5th round of the game, total VP's are added up, with the highest being  deemed the victor.

Name: Star Trek: Attack Wing – Gress'Sril Card Pack
Description:
The Gress'Sril is a Gorn Raider class ship, and is part of the Independent faction. As a card pack, it comes with all the cards and tokens required for play.

It is a part of card pack wave 3.

Name: The Abstractionist
Description:
The Abstractionist! is a game set against a backdrop of the art world in the first decades just after the turn of the 20th century. As a young aspiring artist you find your motivation in the avant garde abstract art movement and the contemporary art scene of the time. Your aim is to become a celebrated artists. You want to become the true abstractionist of this era. At the same time your limited resources and lack of supplies hinders your goal, your work and pursuit of fame and status.

The goal is to make color placements and color combinations in such a way that you end up with the highest score in the end. Every color added to the canvas is a potential scoring opportunity that will move the scoretrack pawn one or several (1-4) steps. If at any point during the game a player reaches the score of twenty (20) points or above, the Endgame Exhibition is triggered and the final scoring begins.  Some color tile combinations scores extra during the scoring and you could score points for your chosen favorite color as long as no one else chosen the same.

Name: AEON2
Description:
WarDice: AEON2 is a new and unique wargame. With a non-standard turn structure and fog of war command system, This game creates a realistic and playable representation of battle. If commanded correctly, troops could move quickly to where they are needed, unless the enemy starts firing at them! Actual tactical operations work in AEON2.

AEON2 also lets you make your own armies from any figures out on the market.  Ask yourself these questions. Should you really know the exact weaponry and strength of the enemy? Should you be able to know the exact rolls he needs to make to be successful when attacking or defending? Should your units do exactly what you want them to do each time? Move to an exact spot? Shoot at the best time? Charge exactly when ordered? React when they are supposed to? Is it too predictable?

For a realistic, but playable set of sci fi rules AEON2 is the rules set you have been looking for.

AEON2 has a ton of great features.  Some of them are listed below:


     Story element to all games
     Commanders that issue orders
     Elite troops
     Different level vehicles
     Random movement system
     6 phase system for turns
     No charts for combat
     Dice vs dice combat
     Fog of war philosophy
     Random game end
     Suppression
     Reaction tests and firing
     Personality for commanders
     Mission Generator
     No two games ever alike
     No bookkeeping
     Marker based morale system
     Plane rules for flying vehicles
     Snipers
     Indirect fire
     Army lists in BattleScribe (free)


—description from the publisher

Name: Cthulhu: XOTHIC WARS – Xothian Acolytes Box
Description:
This box set contains 5 complete Xothian Acolytes. They are the smallest sized Xothians, and each model has arms with spikes. This toughens up the Xothians by adding a unit which hits harder than the initial Supplicants unit from the starter box.

Kits contain 5 Torsos, 5 Legs, 10 Arms with Spikes, and 5 MDF bases

Name: Cthulhu: XOTHIC WARS – Xothian Guard Box
Description:
This box set contains 3 complete Xothian Guards. They are the larger sized standard Xothians, and each model has arms with spikes. While similar to one of the core box units, the spikes deliver a whole lot more damage in combat - allowing these soldiers to carve their way through the enemy lines. Often capable of even handling a Lesser Terrorbeast, this unit makes a solid addition to your force.

Kits contain 3 Torsos, 3 Legs, 6 Arms with Spikes, and 3 MDF bases

Name: Cthulhu: XOTHIC WARS – Xothian Lesser TerrorBeast Box
Description:
This box set contains 1 complete Xothian Lesser TerrorBeast. This is the smaller of the 2 main TerrorBeasts for the Xothians. You may purchase a second model separately, as you can up to 2 in a Unit if you want.

This as the basic level of heavy support for any Xothic Wars army in the field! It is brutally destructive, and capable of grinding through most other Unit types. While 1 is powerful on its own, it takes at least 2 to stop a Greater Terrorbeast.

It contains 1 body, 2 arms, 1 head, 7 chin tentacles, and 1 MDF base.

Name: Cthulhu: XOTHIC WARS – Xothian Greater Terrorbeast Box
Description:
This box contains 1 complete Xothian Greater TerrorBeast. It is the largest of the two types of Terrorbeasts commonly available to the Xothians. It provides a massive level of brute force to your army - which can only be rivaled by an Avatar of the Elder gods. This is also a way to keep the figure count of your army low for scenarios, and still pack a powerful punch. Even a pair of Lessor Terrorbeasts have trouble fighting a single Greater Terrorbeast.

It contains 1 body, 2 arms, 1 head, 7 chin tentacles, and 1 MDF base.

Name: The Red Dragon Inn: Future Brew
Description:
The Red Dragon Inn Organized Play Season 4 Premium Promo; it also appears in The Red Dragon Inn: Allies â€“ Evil Pooky.

Earns 3 alcohol content
Discard any number of cards from your hand, then refill to your hand size.

Name: The Red Dragon Inn: Celebration Shochu
Description:
The Red Dragon Inn Organized Play Season 4 Participation Promo

Earns 2 alcohol contents.
If it's not someone's Drink Phase, chase 1 more

Name: The Quest for El Dorado: Heroes & Hexes
Description:
The Quest for El Dorado: Heroes & Hexes includes three new double-sided terrain tiles that add a new element to the game: curses. When a player stops on a demon space, they must draw and reveal a curse token to see how they're affected. Maybe they have to discard certain cards before they can travel on a particular type of terrain, or perhaps other explorers will move while the cursed one is paralyzed, or maybe you'll be afflicted by a demon, specifically a demon card that's shuffled into your deck and does nothing but frustrate you or get transformed into a half-coin each time you see it.

Why would you travel to a demonic location when bad things would happen to you? Moving to that space doesn't cost a card, so you might just be being cheap, but additionally some demon spaces have tunnels that allow you to move directly from one hex on a tile to another on that same tile. Is that free movement worth the punishment you might suffer? The expansion includes two blockades that bear a demon symbol, and if you're the first to break such a blockade on your quest across the map, you must suffer the curse that follows.

To play with this expansion, you must use the "Caves" variant of The Quest for El Dorado base game in which mountains are loaded with cave tokens. This expansion includes new cave tokens to be mixed with those of the base game, as well as four new types of expedition cards (with three copies of each) that can be pulled into the market once a stall opens.

Each player starts the game with one of four familiars (dealt out at random) in their deck, with each familiar having a repeating power and a one-shot bonus power. For a further way to juice up your deck, you can visit one of the three tavern spaces in the game. When you do this, you draw the top three hero cards of the ten-card deck, place one of those heroes in your hand (after which it becomes a regular part of your deck), then shuffle the other two heroes into the deck. Only one hero per adventuring party, please!

The expansion includes six suggested map set-ups — all at medium or hard levels, and all with three new terrain tiles — as well as guidelines for how to create maps yourself.
Families: Game: The Quest for El Dorado

Name: The Nut Game
Description:
Each season a great game is held to determine who will rule the kingdom on Squirrel Island. You are in this game. Your goal is to gather more nuts than the others, and the name of the game is The Nut Game!

In The Nut Game, players takes turns using their stamina to play Squirrel- and Tool cards and take other actions. Each player builds up his or her own army of squirrels that helps them gather more nuts and secure their own win or their opponents demise. Players can also hide nuts to secure a boost in the scores for the end of the game. It's a game of one-upmanship that can suddenly turn on its head in an instant when one of the devastating event cards are drawn!

Players draw cards from the same pile and when that pile is empty the game is over. Players count how many nuts they've collected, including their hidden ones, and the one who has gathered most nuts wins!

Name: Recycling
Description:
This is a simple web-published paper & pencil game intended to teach the benefits of recycling wastes of different kind to children and their families.

The game comes with a sheet for each player. Some dice and eraserable pencils are required to play.

On your turn, roll three dice. Each number is associated to a different material (1 = plastic, 2 = paper, 3 = glass, 4 = aluminuim, 5 = special stuff, 6 = organic waste), and each material has a different special effect.

For each die you can choose either to keep it or discard it. In the latter case, you get to activate the related special effect - i.e.: paper makes you roll 2 more dice, while glass makes you adjust the value of another die,... - . Mark a X on the Waste track (negative points!) for each die discarded in this way.

Then, for each die you kept, mark a X on the related "building track". When the 5th X of a building track has been marked, you have managed to build the Recycling Plant for the related material, thus you won't mark X on the Waste track anymore for using the related special effect. You also score some points depending on how many other players have preceded you in building the same Recycling Plant.

As soon as a player has built 4 Recycling plants, the game is over and whoever has the most points is the winner.

Name: Dragonfire: Adventures – Corruption in Calimshan
Description: The exotic cities and arid deserts of Calimshan hide wonders untold...and terrors unknown! Conquer new encounters, including the all-new Desert environment. In the shifting sands, claim new Magic Items and Market cards, along with Crafting Poisons, in the next chapter of Dragonfire Adventures!

Name: Micro-Football
Description:
Micro-Football is a sports themed game that is fast-paced, easy to learn, and can be played anywhere requiring very little table space. Challenge yourself or someone else to see who can score the most points, or see who can score first. Sports fans, families and casual gamers alike will enjoy the back-and-forth card play while trying to anticipate your opponent's next move! Features three game modes: Full Game, Solo, and Overtime.

In Micro-Football, players take turns each quarter on offense and defense. The offense has the goal of reaching the Goal Line of the defense for a Touchdown, or get close enough for a Field Goal, while the defense has the goal of stopping them. Each player has seven cards to choose from (only four will be played), and as they are played simultaneously with your opponent, the results of the combined yardage moves the marker along the football field. If one player can consecutively guess their opponents' next card 3-times, they will trigger a Big Play like an automatic touchdown or a turnover. The player with the most points after four quarters wins!

Components
  - 18 cards (7 offense, 7 defense, 4 football field)
  - 4 cubes (2 blue, 2 red) 
  - 1 coin
  - 1 gem (football marker)
  - rulebook

Name: GIFT
Description:
You’ve been invited to a party where everyone’s dead. You’re having a great time when you suddenly realise… you’re dead too! The only way to get back to life is to appease the God of Life. The God of Life seeks sacrifice, but not of the physical kind. You must speak witty sentences and entertain for your passage home.

Letters appear before you, made from the bones of those who disappointed. Each word in your sentence must start with these letters. The God of Life loves certain keywords. If you can secretly put a keyword from a Key Card into your sentence then you gain a Body Part. Collect all 5 to win.

However, the God of Death is also listening. If other players can guess your keyword then they take your Body Parts. Can you outwit the God of Death and entertain the God of Life with some Good Interesting Fun Times?

Name: Smugglers of the Galaxy: Alpha Expansion
Description:
This is a free print-and-play expansion to the base game.

It contains enhanced, optional strategy and solo play rules. It also enables the creation of custom characters for game play.

Name: Cliques
Description:
Cliques is the quick, fun card game in which you try to be the first to get rid of all your cards by collecting, and playing, same color groups of cute, quirky characters!

How To Play
Shuffle the deck and deal all players 10 cards. Set the remaining deck face down, which shall have a single discard pile beside it. The player left of the dealer takes the first turn.

For every turn, the player shall draw 1 card (from the deck or the discard pile), and conclude it by discarding 1 card. Prior to discard, the player may set down 3 cards of the same color, face-up on the playing surface, as a "clique." Any player may also add 2 more cards of the same color to any clique of 3 to increase it to 5. Cliques may only ever be a total of 3 or 5 cards. Only 1 clique of each color is permitted. Any number of cliques may be created, or added to, during a turn. Play moves clockwise. Ninjas can join any clique to finish it. Zombies are played singularly on any clique to eat it, remove it from play and send 1 card of that clique into the hand of the opponent of the player's choice.

When any player discards all cards, or the game deck is exhausted, the hand is over. Players score 1 point for each card they still hold.

The player with the least points, wins!

—description from the publisher

Name: Huzzah! Honey Springs
Description:
Fire in the Nations
The Battle of Honey Springs; Indian Territory (Oklahoma), 
July 17th 1863

Huzzah! simulates American Civil War combat at the grand-tactical level. The system features encounters little known yet strategically significant. These are fights that, had they concluded differently, might well have transformed a campaign, a reputation, or both. So, although the battles in Huzzah! were little more than scrimmages compared to, say, Gettysburg or Stones River, they were not insignificant, bearing weight well beyond what mere numbers suggest.

The Battle of Honey Springs, July 17, 1863, was an important victory for Union forces in their efforts to gain control of the Indian Territory. The largest confrontation between Union and Confederate forces in the area that would eventually become Oklahoma, the engagement was unique in that African and Native Americans made up significant portions of each of the opposing armies.

Components:
1 x 17x22 Map/Playing Surface
1 x Sheet of Die-Cut, Mounted, Full-Color Playing Pieces
1 x Book of Game Specific Rules
1 x Book of Rules
1 x Player Aid Card

Solitaire Suitability: 7 out of 10
Complexity: 7 out of 10
Folio No. 12

Name: Cream of the Crop
Description:
Competing farmers are all trying to use the same farmland to grow their crops. They realized that in order to keep the pests away it's best to mix the crops they grow onto the same field. The challenge is that the farmers can't agree on who should plant which crops.

Players use seeds (coins) or dice to move their tractors (pawns) around the board while trying to form patterns with the seeds. Successful patterns are rewarded with prizes from the county fair and collecting enough prizes wins the game. The seeds grow four different crops: arms are almonds, crowns are corn, moons are melons, and suns are sunflower seeds.

On your turn, choose whether you're going to move using a seed or a die. Seed - Pick a seed from your hand, and show the value to the other players. Play the seed suit side up on the board space under your tractor, and move the tractor. The seed's suit tells you which direction to move and the seed's value tells you how far to move. Die - Choose the die for the direction you want to move. Roll the die to determine how far you move in that direction.

If you finish your move on a space with a seed, pick it up and place it in your hand.
If you finish your move on another player's tractor, pick it up and place it in any empty space on the board.
If you created a diagonal, vertical, or horizontal line with three seeds of one suit, take the prize tile of that suit from the county fair. A line of four seeds with one of each suit collects the grid tile as a mixed harvest prize.

Collect three prizes to win. In a four player game, play as partners with the opposite player and collect three prizes as a team to win.

Name: The Walking Dead: No Sanctuary – Better Angels
Description:
The expansion's Player vs Player Scenario recreates Rick and Shane's fight to the death in the classic episode "Better Angels."

From the Kickstarter summary page:

In the “Better Angels” Scenario, Rick and Shane start out on opposite sides of a typical 2x2 board, which includes the special Misty Forest Tile. Shane begins the game wounded, with 2 Survivor Cards in his discard pile and a hand of only 3 cards. However, Shane is hiding something from Rick: his Shotgun! The Shotgun Survivor Card is set aside and the player controlling Shane has a Map Card that only he or she can look at. If Shane ever gets to the secret Space indicated on the Map Card, he gets to add the Shotgun directly to his hand, swinging the odds wildly in his favor.

But Rick has some advantages of his own in this one-on-one battle to the death! Rick starts the Scenario with more health and is considered the Leader during the entire Scenario (which may be one of the reasons Shane has such a problem with him!). Just like any regular Scenario of THE WALKING DEAD: NO SANCTUARY, the Leaders draws 2 Event Cards, choosing 1 card to become the Active Event and discarding the other card, causing a penalty for all players. The difference when playing PvP is that a character who is Defiant to the Approach set by the Active Event only hurts his own cause, since he is the only one who earns the resulting Stress.

The Scenario ends when either Rick or Shane is killed by his opponent. However, since this is the world of The Walking Dead, when Shane is “killed” he rises again as a Walker one turn later, with the regular Shane figure replaced by the Walker Shane figure. The player controlling Shane will also have control of all the other Walkers on the board. Rick will need to put down his former friend a second time to win!

Name: Warhammer Underworlds: Shadespire – Spiteclaw's Swarm
Description:
Includes 5 Skaven miniatures and a deck of 60 cards, 30 of which are universal, to be used by any and every warband – add these cards to your arsenal and build your perfect deck.

- 5 Easy To Build, brown plastic Skaven miniatures: Skritch Spiteclaw, Krrk the Almost-Trusted, Lurking Skaven, Hungering Skaven, and Festering Skaven;

Name: Warhammer Underworlds: Shadespire – The Chosen Axes
Description:
Includes 4 Fyreslayers miniatures and a deck of 60 cards, 30 of which are universal, to be used by any and every warband – add these cards to your arsenal and build your perfect deck.

- 4 Easy To Build, orange plastic Fyreslayers miniatures: Fjul-Grimnir, Tef Flamebearer, Mad Maegrim, and Vol Orrukbane;

Name: Swindled
Description:
Swindled is a family party card game for ages 8+.  The game features over 40 different playable cards created loads of mini-games.  Build your hand by drawing from the deck, stealing cards from others' hands, and playing games to win more cards.  If you can't build your own hand, try to sabotage others by placing car bombs, giving someone a disease, or starting a bar fight.

The base game plays two to eight players, with the ability to add expansions packs to play up to 12 players.

—description from the publisher

Name: Treacherous
Description:
Treacherous is a sci-western hidden identity game taking 2-7 players into a dangerous saloon where the law ends at the swinging doors!

In Treacherous, players compete to have either the most money after the final round or to be the last player still at the table.

During each round, the first player will ante to the pot. Then, in clockwise order, each player will use either a card action and a standard action OR if you're willing to gamble a little of your gems, 2 standard actions. Standard actions allow the player to draw new Grifters or Lady Luck cards, or take income in the form of a gem from the bank. Card actions are found not only on the Grifters, but also the Lady Luck cards.

Each player will have a hand that consists of three Lady Luck cards and 1 Grifter card. The grifter is 1 of 7 vile characters from across the universe that you will use to guide you, lie about, or pay to exchange. The Lady Luck cards are poker style cards with abilities of their own and if you're lucky, could win a poker game for you.

Players are dismissed when they lose a challenge. Once dismissed, they may pay gems to challenge the dismissing player to a duel. If they challenge and win, they are back in the game. If they challenge and lose, they are eliminated. They play rounds equal to the number of players plus two OR until only one player remains. If they make it to the end, the active players play poker.

Now, none of this truly matters to the criminals that wander into this saloon. LIE all you want. Just don't get caught! Or...get caught and challenge your accuser to a duel in the street to win your way back into the game and unlock an amazing Vengeance ability that could turn the tide of the game!

So GAMBLE, CHEAT, DUEL, DISTRACT, or TELL THE TRUTH...Just WIN

Name: Monsters!!
Description:
A card game where you play cards to earn or steal points. Players must gain the most points by the time Dracula is drawn from the deck. Each card features a different classic horror monster, each with their own action to use when played. Some cards give players the option to earn extra points by howling, groaning for brains or generally being monstrous.
There are 50 Monster cards, 25 Score Cards and 1 instruction sheet in each retail box.

—description from the publisher

Name: Shadowfist: Throne War
Description: Throne War is a booster-only expansion set released by Z-Man Games in August 2000 along with Year of the Dragon. It's an 80-card set that contains 69 new cards, with rarities divided into Common, Uncommon, and Rare. The other 11 cards are reprints of Daedalus cards, or appear in Year of the Dragon as well.

Name: UPRISE
Description:
Uprise is a tower-building game that plays Solo, Co-Op, or Competitively.

You're a member of a new secret society.

Complete all missions to overthrow the ruling elite.

Each mission card comes with its own set of supplies. If playing Solo or Co-Op, share the inventory among all the members in your group. If playing competitively, each member attempts to climb the ranks on their own so each of them needs the inventory indicated.

CONTENTS & GENERAL FUNCTIONS

1. MISSION CARDS
The goal of the mission is stated on the Mission Card. Complete all the missions so that your secret society can grow.

Types of missions:

a) Score-Based Missions: reach a certain number of points before running out of 'Stache Cards.

b) Architect Missions: replicate a certain design before running out of 'Stache Cards.

c) Checklist Missions: complete the requirements on a checklist before running out of 'Stache Cards.

2. TOP HAT CARDS
Disguised with a Top Hat, you can infiltrate a new country by revealing what is known as a Top Hat Card.
Top Hat Cards are divided into 9 squares (1 flag and 8 location squares). While you cannot place anything on a flag square, you are considered to have set up a bureau on the flag square the moment you gain access to that country. For this reason, flag squares will count toward completing Secret Agendas.

3. 'STACHE CARDS
Disguised with a 'Stache, you are able to set up bureaus across the world. Each 'Stache Card contains a location where you can potentially set up 1 bureau. To set up a bureau, you must discard the 'Stache Card and place your bureau on the proper tile.

If you cannot or choose not to use a 'Stache Card to set up a bureau, hide the card in your Vault. Rest assure you'll be able to use it later to make investments.

4. YOUR VAULT
This is where ALL 'Stache Cards not used to place a bureau must go at the end of a round. On any later turn, you will be able to use the $ VALUE to make investments. A list of investments is found on the back of the Vault.

5. BUREAUS
These unmarked buildings are setup locations so that your secret society may operate in that country. Be careful when setting your bureau. Should it lead to exposure due to lack of stability, you'll lose this bureau and likely others as well.

6. SECRET AGENDAS
To accelerate your mission, try to complete Secret Agendas. Secret Agendas are patterns you'll want to achieve within any given country. These patterns are determined by the placement of the flag, the placement of bureaus, as well as the placement of decoys.

Generally there is more than one way to complete a Secret Agenda and you can reveal all your options by rotating the card.

Once you complete a Secret Agenda, you may choose to cover up your presence in that country and move onto the next. You can do this free of charge as long as the Secret Agenda has been achieved.

The Cover Up consist of adding a new Top Hat Card ON TOP the components required to complete the Secret Agenda. As long as you successfully manage to do this, you will also Cover Up your completed Secret Agenda Card with a new Secret Agenda Card.

7. TOP HATS
A Top Hat is an opportunity to enter a new country without completing a Secret Agenda. You can gain a Top Hat by purchasing it from the 'Stache Cards in your Vault or you can also gain one by placing a Bureau on a tile with a Top Hat SYMBOL.

When using a Top Hat, you can either
a) cover up component(s) from an already existing tower and climb UP.
b) start a new branch by adding a new Top Hat Card on the ground floor.

8. DECOYS
Decoys can be placed on the tile of your choice (except on a flag) without needing to play a 'Stache Card.

You can gain a Decoy by purchasing it from the 'Stache Cards in your Vault or you can also gain one by placing a Bureau on a tile with a SUITCASE SYMBOL.

Decoys count as a yellow square in terms of your Secret Agendas. They can also be used to provide stability in a country.

9. BRIDGES
Bridges, when required, merge together separate branches within your organization. The need for bridges is determine by your chosen Mission Card.

There are no fees for placing a bridge(s). However, for a merger to be completed, you will need to cover the bridge(s) with a new Top Hat Card. Do this by using a Top Hat.

10. CRISIS CARDS
These cards are for competitive play only. They enable you to run an interference in another member's plans.

Crisis Cards are purchased.

—description from the publisher

Name: What's the Name of the Game?!
Description:
Also known as The Colander Game, The Hat Game and The Celebrity Game, this is a fast-paced guessing game where players put cards with the names of famous people on them into a colander, bowl or hat and teams take turns to act, speak or dance clues. Guaranteed to bring out players’ competitive streaks!

Similar to Celebrities

Name: Dungeon Twister: Amazone
Description:
The Amazone is a mini expansion for the Dungeon Twister series of games.  Its stats are Movement 3, Combat 3. She has the ability to seduce an opposing male character in an adjacent field. This then performs (3 AP) valid actions in the interests of the Amazon.

Originally the character of the Collector's Box of the old base game was included (at least as a stand-up, the figure had to be ordered separately), the Amazon will be included in a slightly different form in the new extension "Fallen".

Name: Sumtastic
Description:
Sumtastic is a math based board game.

Single play
Solo players will play against a timer, trying to beat their own score with each play.

Multi-player
The players write their names on the score card and write a total number that the game is to be won once it is reached (example 500)

Players roll two dice, the score is then the total number which the player must move to on the playing board. A sum square is placed onto the board with the number in the center of it, around the frame are +,-,x,?. The player picks a tile randomly from the bag which must be used to complete the sum. The total is then added to the score card. The winner is the first person to reach the total.

If doubles are rolled, the players have an additional turn. If three doubles in a row are thrown the player misses a turn.

If a player removes a ? from the tile bag they may choose there own sum (substitute the ? For either a x, + or - )

Modified play 
Play is available with the addition or subtraction of tiles which will effect the maths sum options.

The game is a wooden made playing board, sum frame and tiles.

Name: Partition
Description:
Partition is a 2-player campaign tournament system consisting of three card games all based on popular eSports gaming genres: FPS, MOBA and CCG. Each game can be played without even owning the other games, offering a familiar experience to their online counterparts, but with cards. When combined together with the Partition core box, the games form the Partition Grand Tournament, a three-match contest to decide once and for all who can build the best team of Gamers and lead them to victory!

—descro[topm frp,  the designer

Name: Gambo
Description:
Pieces confront in a series of duels.
The difference is that you see all your opponent’s pieces, that you choose your angle of attack, and that the pieces obey a circular hierarchy : in absolute terms, nobody is the strongest.
As you initiate the next duel when you have just lost one, it may be occasionally advantageous to lose.
Sometimes it happens that some sacrificial dynamics lead you to the final victory.
The figurines are simply pinched within their bases, and you can pinch them in again when removed.

To engage a duel, the player moves a piece to the line of battle. The opponent must chose one of the 2 pieces on the left and on the right of the played piece and move it to join the line of battle.
The elephants scratch the cats, the cats eat the mice, the mice frighten the elephants. Between the same pieces, a level 3 beats a level 2, who beats a level 1. The next duel is engaged by the player who has captured the less prisoners.
The goal of the game is to eliminate all of the opponent’s pieces.

Name: Wings of War: The Dawn of World War II – Aichi D3A1 Val
Description:
Take your Wings of War game into the third dimension! Each historically-accurate, fully-painted miniature represents an aircraft from Wings of War: The Dawn of World War II. All miniatures come complete with maneuver deck and variable-altitude stand. This Japanese dive-bomber participated throughout the war, including at Pearl Harbor.

—description from the publisher

Name: Alles an Bord?!: Das diebische Äffchen
Description:
The promo card "Das diebische Äffchen" (The thieving monkey) is on the last page of the Abacus Spiele games catalogue 2018.

At the beginning of the game, players draw 4 equipment tiles and put them on the monkey. These tiles cannot be collected in this round. 
At the end of a round, the tiles are put back with the rest and four new tiles will be drawn and put on the monkey card.

With the promo card, the difficulty is a little bit higher.

Name: Gem Quest
Description:
Gem Quest is the fun and simple card game in which you try to be the first to buy and collect sets of matching jewels, while attempting to stop your opponents from doing the same!

How To Play
Shuffle the deck and deal all players 5 cards. If a player gets an "Action" card, it must be traded in for a replacement. Blindly insert said action card back into the deck. Set the deck face down between all players, which shall have a discard pile beside it.
The player left of the dealer takes the first turn.

For each turn, the player flips the deck's top card onto the discard pile. If it's an Action card, take the action (if possible). If it's a coin, the player takes it in to hand. If it's a gem, the player may put coins equal (or greater) to its value on the discard pile to buy it into hand. If the player cannot afford (or doesn't want) the gem, remove it to a field of cards on the playing surface (the Gem Store), from which gems may be bought during one's turn by paying coins to the discard pile. Change is not given.

When a pair of the same gem is collected, it must be set down for all to see. A third of that gem may be added to make a trio. The diamond counts as a pair or trio by itself. Play moves clockwise. If the deck exhausts, reuse the discard pile.

The first to get 3 pairs, or 2 trios, of gems, wins!

Name: Punkin Fight
Description:
It's a rainy, Halloween Night. You're under attack. A rival gang is lobbing Punkin Bombs at your various clubhouses around town—trying to bring them down, and take over your turf. It's time to fight back!

How To Play
Separate the "Clubhouse" cards from the deck and deal 3 face-up in front of each player. Place the rest of the deck face down between all players. The player left of the dealer has first turn.

For each turn, players draw up to 5 cards (the hand limit), and then may play only 1 card of each card type. Punkin Bomb cards are played in front of a player's house to attack it. Witch cards are played behind a house to strengthen it. Ghost cards are played on the last bomb placed on a house to remove it to the discard pile, and Vampire cards may be paired with a card to play an extra card of that type during a turn. A turn is over when no card can be played. If a player already has 5 cards at the start of a turn, draw 1 more card. Play continues clockwise.

When the total value of all Punkin Bombs played on a Clubhouse equals (or eclipses) its value (plus the value of Witch cards behind it), the Clubhouse is destroyed/removed from play. All cards played on the Clubhouse go to the discard pile. Should the game deck exhaust, reuse the discard pile.

The last player with a Clubhouse left, wins!

Name: Kill Them All
Description:
The time is now for us to rid the world of a greatly annoying creature that is the bane of human life as we know it. Emojis are so stupid, and really hard to kill. Even so... Kill them. Kill Them All.

How To Play
Separate all 12 Emoji cards from the deck. Shuffle these cards and deal 3 to all players, face-up, in front of them. Set aside extra Emojis. Shuffle the remaining deck and set it face-down between all players. A discard pile exists beside it. The player to the dealer's left has first turn.

For each turn, players draw up to 4 cards (the hand limit) from the deck (or discard pile, or both), and play any number of Weapon cards into the spaces below the 3 Emoji cards that (and only if they) list them. When all Weapons listed on an Emoji have been played, flip it over, as it is dead, and place the weapons used to kill it under the discard pile, to be reused later. If a player is unable to play a Weapon on an Emoji during a turn, one must be played on an opponent's Emoji of his or her choice. If neither are possible, the player must show his or her hand to all. To end a turn, 1 card is discarded (if possible). If the deck exhausts, reuse the discard pile.

Use Special Action cards by playing them onto the discard pile (from where they may not be drawn).

The first to kill all of his or her Emojis wins!

Name: Android: Netrunner – Kampala Ascendent
Description:
Kampala Ascendent finishes the Kitara Cycle, introducing a piece of hardware that allows you to spend a click to receive a credit and two cards, an operation that can eliminate three of a runner’s clicks on a turn, a new Jinteki identity that invites the runners into their servers, and so much more.

Complete your journey into the SSL with Kampala Ascendent!

—description from the publisher
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)

Name: The Networks: Telly Time
Description:
The Networks: Telly Time, an expansion for The Networks, features nine genres and a new "noughts-and-crosses" way to get a genre bonus, with the shows in this item likely to be familiar to those from the UK. Telly Time comes in a small tuckbox, which contains 59 cards and 35 small plastic chips. Most of the cards are new TV shows.

45 of the cards in Telly Time are brand new Shows. There are three new Genres represented:

Chat Shows have a special power: the moment you Develop one, you may rotate all Stars and Ads in one of your timeslots (including the one the Chat Show is going in) to their good sides.

Quiz Shows also have a special power: at the end of each Season, you may use any Quiz Shows active in your lineup to convert money into Viewers at a rate of $1M to 1 Viewer, up to $3M for 3 Viewers for each active Quiz Show in your lineup.

Kids Shows have no special explicit powers, but tend to get you a lot of Viewers for their cost, and you can stuff them with Ads. But they only want to go on your earliest slot, with a big penalty if you put them on in the wrong time slot.

Note that you must have The Networks base game in order to play Telly Time! The Networks: Telly Time is partially compatible with The Networks: On the Air. The designer doesn't recommend playing it with the Shows from On the Air, but it will work just fine with the Stars, Ads, and Network Cards from On the Air.

The Networks: Telly Time is fully compatible with The Networks: Executives. Mogul Cards work the same way, except that you pick them up when you move the marker on your Genre-Bonus-O-Meter to the end.

Name: DC Deck-Building Game: Crisis Expansion Pack 4
Description:
DC Comics Deck-Building Game: Crisis Expansion Pack 4 introduces the keyword "Unity" for ongoing cards that get better as more teammates have them in play. The pack focuses on the Teen Titans and includes six superheroes from the Titans, original members of the group who are now all grown up and have something to prove.

Another fresh twist to gameplay comes in the form of personal crisis cards, which may directly affect only one character, but can still take down the whole team if players don't work together to solve the problem.

Name: Crickets
Description:
The time is ripe for some gold old-fashioned family fun!

Plant three to six players around the table and let the mayhem begin as you race to plant the most crops and reap the most point.  Fill your fields with wheat, oats, corn or beans.  But watch out for those pesky crickets, because they'll devour everything in their path-unless, of course, you enlist the help of the famously faithful seagulls.  You could also be hit by other hazards, like a wildfire or even a drought so dry the cows are giving evaporated milk.

And while it's a good idea to love your neighbor, watch out: he or she might just send come crickets your way.  And don't forget that others can use a Helping Hand card to help themselves to your hand!  When the dust finally settles, you're sure to find a harvest of fun for everyone with Crickets

Players start with 5 cards each, on your turn you draw one card and play a card. Play crops on one of your two fields, trying to fill it with five crop cards. Upon harvest, shuffle 4 of the cards back in the draw pile and keep one for scoring purposes.  A player can also play crickets on each other's fields to cause the player to have crops eaten each turn. Play immediately cards have a black border and happen immediately and are things like fires and sick seagulls.

First to 30 points wins!

Name: Zooronga
Description:
The World's Greatest Zoo

The director of Zooronga is retiring and you’re one of the few zookeepers who could be chosen to assume this most coveted position! Do you have what it takes to run the greatest zoo the world has ever seen? Compete with the other zookeepers to find the most exotic animals, design the best enclosures, and create the most beautiful gardens and pathways for your lucky patrons to enjoy. Prove that you are capable of attracting the most visitors to your zoo and you might just become the new director of Zooronga - the World’s Greatest Zoo!

Zooronga is a zoo-building, tile-laying game. Each player is a zookeeper with some money and a place to start. The game lasts for five months and each month 5 zoo-tiles are auctioned for the highest bidder. At the end of the month points are calculated. Each zoo-tile contains two animal enclosures of animals from different regions (eg. polar animals, African animals etc), some roads and possibly trees.

Each player secretly selects the amount of money he is willing to pay for the tile and the highest bidder wins the auction. Whenever a tile is bought it needs to be added to your zoo so that the roads and green areas match. It might be that after the tile is added to your zoo, your zoo becomes more interesting than before. Interest value is shown with little stars on the tiles. The more stars of one color you have, the more interesting your zoo is for that region. Visitors are also interested in trees and parks. Visitors always go for the most interesting zoos and at the end of the month each visitor in your zoo gives you points. When the month ends, each player receives some income and new zoo-tiles are drawn for auction.

The goal is to attract as many visitors to your zoo as possible and thus score more points than others.

Name: Merca-Tiny
Description:
A new market has opened in the city square. Great business opportunity awaits the most enterprising merchants.

Who will be the richest of the square (the winner), in the end?

As a trader, each player on their turn can open new stalls (place one or more stall-tiles) following the strict municipal rules or bring new customers to the market (move a customer). In the city, customers have a somewhat extravagant and habitual behavior: they always walk straight ahead until they meet stalls, then they always turn around counterclockwise; they buy clothes and shoes in any order, but only vegetables or fish after buying vegetables, and only other fish, after they buying fish. Obviously customers buy only products that are on their shopping list.
 Try to open your stalls in strategic position and keep an eye on price trends: the best selling goods will be more expensive in the next rounds. But stalls of a goods type can inflate that goods.

Meanwhile, beware of thieves, workers, policeman and many other characters that could benefit (or damage) your (or opponents) business: You have action disks that can be spent to pick-up and/or use special actions of such characters.

Be careful to plan your actions in time, as the market is divided into phases, marked by the opening of increasingly modern stalls: during the game the old stalls will be scrapped. When all the stalls are exhausted or when at least one of the goods has reached the maximum price, the market will be closed and the game will be over.

Name: PUCK!
Description:
PUCK! is the ultimate test of your trick shot skills in an all-out puck slamming, cup stacking melee! Race to eliminate your opponents’ cups by landing wooden discs into them, before they land one in yours! Work your way up to the coveted PUCK! For added difficulty, see if you have what it takes to compete at the grandmaster level! This high-stakes game hones your hand-eye coordination and mental agility while testing your focus (and possibly friendships) as you race to win. On your mark, get set, PUCK!
—from the back of the box

PUCK! is a fast and rowdy action/dexterity game where you bounce wooden pucks (discs) off the table and race to land them in small plastic cups also on the table. After you successfully land a puck in a cup, you stack an empty cup on top of it making your next target more difficult to hit as well as bringing the game closer to an end.

PUCK! has several different game modes including head-to-head, free-for-all, and team play and is either turn-based or real-time. Each mode has different cup layouts and end-game conditions, but all utilize the same simple and fun operation of bouncing pucks and stacking cups. PUCK! comes with 40 wooden pucks and 11 plastic cups. 
—user summary

Name: Les Recettes Pompettes: Le Jeu – Deuxième Tournée!
Description:
Les Recettes pompettes - le jeu is back for a second round with 37 new challenges. An evening you will remember for a long time ... or not!

Just shuffle the new challenge cards in with the rest of them and proceed as normal.

Name: Le jeu aux mille titres
Description:
Le jeu aux mille titres ("The Game with a Thousand Titles") is a memory game in which tokens are placed face down on one side of a double-sided game board. On a turn, a player tries to locate a matching couple, but the main hook of the game is that players are encouraged to create a stories as they do so based on where the tokens are located. Did you find the boss in prison and the employee at the park? Tell us why!

This storytelling potential is carried through with the packaging of the game as each cover of the game is unique! In the first edition of the game in 2015, each game also bore a unique title, such as "The Mother in the Clouds" or "The Vampire in the Yard", but this made it difficult for people to identify the game. The second edition in 2018 carries the Le jeu aux mille titres title at top, along with a unique title for the artwork along the bottom of the box, as if the art were a painting in a museum.

Name: Firefly Adventures: Brigands and Browncoats – Respectable Folk
Description: Respectable Folk is a Crew Expansion set for the Firefly Adventure: Brigands and Browncoats game.  The Respectable Folk set includes companion Inara Serra and preacher Shepherd Book. Each new Crew Member adds new skills and abilities to your adventures. The Crew Expansion comes with four Crew miniatures (in both Casual and Heroic poses), two double-sided Crew cards, ten Equipment cards, two new Jobs and the box bottom also doubles as a new building.

Name: Firefly Adventures: Brigands and Browncoats – Wanted Fugitives
Description: Wanted Fugitives is a Crew Expansion set for the Firefly Adventure: Brigands and Browncoats game.  The Wanted Fugitives set includes physician Simon Tam and the gifted River Tam. Each new Crew Member adds new skills and abilities to your adventures. The Crew Expansion comes with four Crew miniatures (in both Casual and Heroic poses), two double-sided Crew cards, ten Equipment cards, two new Jobs and the box bottom also doubles as a new building.

Name: Army of Roussillon: Les Folies d'Espagne – The War of the Grand Alliance in Spain, 1689-1697
Description:
Army of Roussillon (AOR) is the eleventh volume in the Lace Wars series and the first in a set of four dealing with the War of the Grand Alliance (1688-1697). This war, sometimes called the War of the League of Augsburg or the Nine Years War, was the second of the three great wars of Louis XIV. As a young man he waged the Dutch War to expand France's borders. This was a war of aggression. As an old man he fought the War of the Spanish Succession to put his grandson on the throne of Spain. Despite the King's ultimate aim this was a defensive war. The War of the Grand Alliance was Louis' war of middle age - a war of grinding attrition involving nearly a million men.

Spain, then ruled by the Bourbon kings' great rival, the House of Habsburg, joined the Grand Alliance, but she soon wished she had not. The Army of the Sun King was the premiere military machine of its age, the Spanish Army a fallen titan. Nevertheless, the Spanish saw the war through to its end. While her exhausted allies struck secret peace deals, Spain fought on. Only with the taking of Barcelona in 1697 did she sue for peace - and the decision to capitulate came from Madrid, not its garrison. Barcelona held for 63 days against a massive bombardment and multiple assaults that left 15,000 French dead on her glacis and in her shattered bastions. By the end, both sides were wondering if they would have the strength to fight another round.

Catalonia was a secondary front. For much of the war the French fielded fewer men than the Spanish and were kept on a tight leash. The man in charge, Anne Jules de Noailles, II Duc de Noailles, was governor of Roussillon, formerly part of Catalonia. His Intendant, or 'commissar', was a Catalan. They hoped to harness one of the periodic peasant revolts that plagued the region and 'win hearts and minds' for France - or at least keep the Army of Spain dancing to their tune. Unfortunately, Noailles could not get his subordinates to buy into this program; the arrogance inherent in traditional military culture alienated the population and the French found themselves involved in a nasty guerrilla war. Only after Spain's allies began to withdraw from the struggle were the French able to bring overwhelming force to bear against her.

In AOR, you will have a chance to change history - and even if you cannot, perhaps you can win enough glory to write your name in the history books.

As the French, will you pursue a hearts and minds strategy, or try for all out conquest? Will you occupy territory or make surgical strikes aided by your fleet? (Be warned, the family that runs the Ministry of Marine is at odds with the family that runs the Ministry of War.) The French Army is state-of-the-art. You have more artillery, the latest equipment (bayonets instead of pikes), and access to an administrative machine capable of supporting nearly 500,000 men. But you command a secondary front. Versailles will forever be taking regiments away from you, forcing you to rely on local militia and even Catalan renegades. If you garrison every post, you will be too weak to go on the offensive. If you give up captured fortresses to concentrate, the local population will believe you are weak and rise against you. If you do nothing, you will lose the respect of the Sun King and the Court ladies.

As the Spanish, can you keep the French at bay? Or can you damage them enough to try a counter-invasion of Roussillon? Will the English send their fleet and land troops to aid you? Or, will the Holy Roman Emperor divert his attention from the Turks long enough to spare you some Imperial regiments? The Spanish Army, led by a succession of viceroys who often found themselves more in conflict with the local Catalan government than with the French, is a motley collection of regular regiments (the tercios), decent cavalry, poorly motivated and equipped militia, and mercenaries. Spain's best assets are her guerrillas, the migueletes, assisted by vigilante bands known as somaten, and the mountainous Catalan terrain.

Components

1) Two map sections representing the northeast corner of Spain at one league (4 Km) per hex.

2) 600 die cut counters representing the forces of the French and the Spanish and their allies. Scale is Battalion - that is, the playing pieces represent battalions and regiments.

3) Rules, charts, tables, and display cards.

4) An historical commentary.

Name: Army of Italy: Le Divertissement Royale – The War of the Grand Alliance in Italy, 1690-1696
Description:
Army of Italy (AOI) is the twelfth volume in the Lace Wars series and the second in a set of four dealing with the War of the Grand Alliance (1688-1697). This war, sometimes called the War of the League of Augsburg or the Nine Years War, was the second of the three great wars of Louis XIV. As a young man he waged the Dutch War to expand France's borders. This was a war of aggression. As an old man he fought the War of the Spanish Succession to put his grandson on the throne of Spain. Despite the King's ultimate aim this was a defensive war. The War of the Grand Alliance was Louis' war of middle age - a war of grinding attrition involving nearly a million men.

The war opened in Germany, but the Habsburgs, France's Great Enemy, also owned, or had suzerainty over, much of northern Italy. Coalition forces in Italy were weak, the Habsburg Emperor more concerned with his ongoing war against the Turks. However, the French could not spare many regiments for a second front. But, in 1689, the Spanish Habsburgs also declared war on France, fearing for their lands in the Low Countries. Unfortunately, this put their northern Italian possession of Milan squarely in King Louis' sights. This was a place the French felt they could take, but they would have to be quick about it. There was one potential obstacle: the House of Savoy.

Duke Victor II Amadeus was a French puppet. But, he was also a vassal of the Emperor. And, he coveted Milan for himself... The French planned to cross the Duke's lands, which straddled the western Alps, and launch their invasion of Milan from that state's borders. The mistake King Louis made was to assume Duke Victor would obey his will regardless of how he was treated. The arrogance of the French soldiers and their king combined with Duke Victor's self interest and Coalition gold to push him into the Allied camp. He refused access to the French and found himself at war with them. The Duke was a complex character. Young and valiant, he desired glory over the French in battle, but soon found himself outmatched while his allies proved unreliable. Yet at the same time, he understood how to dissemble and manipulate. What he could not achieve on the battlefield he accomplished in a backroom deal that bought him not only a separate peace with France in 1696, but command over the very French army he had been fighting for the past six years! It was he who led the invasion of Milan!

The war in Italy typified military campaigning in this period. Thwarted in their plans to invade Milan from Piedmont, the French attacked Duke Victor, spilling out of the alpine passes and across Piedmont. But, they could not establish a permanent base and had to withdraw. This flow and ebb was a feature of the early years. Sieges and battles were fought but none brought a lasting advantage to either side. In 1692 the Coalition in turn invaded France but found themselves plagued by the same problems that had beset the French. By 1694 the situation was deadlocked, both militarily and politically. However, on the political front, Duke Victor and King Louis were gradually approaching an accommodation. In 1695 the Sun King at last made some hard concessions. The following year Europe was shocked to learn Duke Victor had changed sides. His defection began the rush to peace, as the Powers tried to obtain the best deal possible for themselves.

In Army of Italy, you will have a chance to change history - and even if you cannot, perhaps you can win enough glory to write your name in the history books.

As the French, will you steamroller your ungrateful puppet state or simply make life so uncomfortable that she decides to join you after all? Then, the invasion of Milan can begin. The French Army is state-of-the-art. You have more artillery, the latest equipment (bayonets instead of pikes), and access to an administrative machine capable of supporting nearly 500,000 men. But you command a secondary front. Versailles will forever be taking regiments away from you, forcing you to rely on your wits. If you garrison every post, you will be too weak to go on the offensive. If you do nothing, you will lose the respect of the Sun King and the Court ladies.

As the Coalition, can you keep the French at bay? Or can you damage them enough to try a counter-invasion of France? Will the English send their fleet and land troops to aid you? Or, will the Holy Roman Emperor divert his attention from the Turks long enough to spare you some Imperial regiments. Duke Victor is not to be trusted. His actions belie his noble declarations. If you are not careful, the House of Savoy may surrender or even switch sides...

Components:

1) Five map sections representing the region of the Maritime Alps and the upper Po Valley at one league (4 Km) per hex. The fifth map shows the main area of conflict, allowing players to dispense with some of the maps for most scenarios, in case space is at a premium.

2) 840 die cut counters representing the forces of the French and their opponents - Savoyards, Huguenots, Waldensians, Spanish, Austrian, and German. Scale is Battalion - that is, the playing pieces represent battalions and regiments.

3) Rules, charts, tables, and display cards.

4) An historical commentary.

Name: Castella
Description:
Two players play as bees and collect honey. The greedy bear will destroy the hive in the process to get the honey. To help their owner taste the delicious honey cake, players have to consider how to place their boards and collect resources. With mutual interference, the player who collects the most honey cakes wins.

How to play


    Steps of the game


Step 1. Get 1 hexagon card and select Honeycomb Side or Garden Side. It's needed to connect any side of the hexagon when placed.

Step 2. Take actions of the card. A player can choose any hexagon card on the table and take its associated action.


    Example of actions for the cards


Honeycomb Side of the card  >  Honey producing or honey
